Vincent Spruyt
8.1k Views • Upvoted by
William Emmanuel Yu, Chief Nerd. PHB and PHD.
Originally Answered: How do I become a data scientist?
This really depends on your background, but for most of us, learning how to program efficiently is the easy part. The problem is that many data-scientists start using machine learning toolboxes and libraries such as Python's Scikit-Learn, without having a basic understanding of the theoretical foundations of the algorithms. I strongly believe that such a black-box approach will leave you with a handicap in the future, as more data scientists emerge.

I would recommend to start by reading some books about probability theory, pattern recognition and machine learning. My top-4 machine learning books for beginners:
  1. Pattern Classification - Richard O. Duda
  2. Machine Learning - Tom M. Mitchell
  3. Pattern Recognition and Machine Learning - Christopher Bishop
  4. Machine Learning: A Probabilistic Perspective - Kevin P. Murphy
You can find a review of these books, regarding their level of detail and the mathematics on Machine Learning Books - Computer vision for dummies

    Ji Li, data scientist
    4.8k Views • Upvoted by
    Ryan Fox Squire, Neuroscientist Turned Data Scientist
    First of all, you might want to know that data scientist in different companies mean very different functionalities, with different sets of expectations. If you join a team called data science in a company, you will be expected to do what other team members have been doing. If you join a company as the sole data scientist, you will be expected to do whatever may be needed as may be imagined by people there as what a data scientist might be able to do. In bigger companies, you are expected to do either what a traditional analyst does, or what a traditional statistician does.

    Therefore, this question really boils down to which companies you are looking to join - or, if you were to join an academic team to do data science, you are typically expected to support other researchers with their data needs and to bridge those needs with what the existing SWEs are doing.

    We wrote a post on the subject How to become data scientist for free a few months a go I hope that you'll find in helpful.
     
    Statistical analysis and data mining were the top skills that got people hired in 2014 based on LinkedIn analysis of 330 million LinkedIn member profiles. We live in an increasingly data driven world, and businesses are aggressively hiring experts in data storage, retrieval, and analysis. Across the globe, statistics and data analysis skills were highly valued. In the US, India, and France, those skills are in particularly high demand.
    What is data science?
    Data scientist performs research and analysis on data and helps companies to improve business by predicting growth, trends and business insights based on huge amounts of data. Armed with data and analytical results, a top-tier data scientist will then communicate informed conclusions and recommendations across an organizations leadership structure. Successful big data scientists will be in high demand and will be able to earn very nice salaries. But in order to be successful, big data scientists need to have a wide range of skills that until now did not even fit into one department.
    Learning how to become data scientist can be quite costly, with an average cost of $9,600 (according to Harvard Extension School). But if you know which skills employers are looking for you can find many free resources online. That is exactly what we did for you! Below is the required skills set for becoming a data scientist with top 3 free resources to learn each skill online.
    Here are the most required skills for a data scientist position based on ReSkill’s analyses of thousands of job posts and free resources to learn each skill:

    Originally Answered: How do I become a data scientist if I don't have professional experience?
    The best way to become a better scientist is to do more science

    To that end,  I am trying to expand my work through blogging

    Machine Learning

    and creating associated, open source , collaborative,  data science projects, like

    CalculatedContent/tsvm
    to go with
    Machine Learning with Missing Labels:  Transductive SVMs

    These projects are designed bona-fide scientific research projects that require collecting our own data and designing experiments that systematically test specific theoretical ideas. 

    Unlike Kaggle, which is isolated, competitive, and predefined, these projects are meant to be shared, collaborative, and requiring scientific thinking to frame the problem

    Each project involves

    1.  mathematical understanding and advancement
    2.  data science experiments
    3.  developing some code

    We are very open to having collaborators interested in doing novel data science research

    Originally Answered: What are steps to become Data Scientist?
    Most of the data science work is done in Python, R and using Unix tools. Unless you are jumping into the bandwagon of Big Data where your Java knowledge may be superficially applied to work with Hadoop, Spark, or Storm. But believe me, you can work with them without Java.

    So, my point is your Java knowledge would not give you any spring-board to leap to become data scientist. It is more about parsing, knowing Maths, Stats and probability, knowing how to apply and what optimization algorithms are.

    For the rest of the answer you should have searched (also a data scientist job) the prior question that has fabulous answers: How do I become a data scientist?

    Originally Answered: How do I become a data scientist?
    1) infrastructure of data processing, such as Hadoop/MapReduce,  Pig/Hive, and automation/cron.
    2) simple stats about data, such as mean, correlation, and p-value.
    3) algorithms for data modeling,  such as logistic regression, and SVM.
    4) visualization of data, such as chart and table.

    Russell Jurney, Applied Technology Historian
    13.2k Views
    Originally Answered: How do I become a data scientist?
    The school route is well covered.  This is the autodidactic route:

    Look at some common problems solved with machine learning.  Look at problems in your areas of interest with an abundance of available data.  Intersect these sets, pick a problem to solve with ML.  Learn whatever it takes to solve it poorly.  Get people using the output of your model.  Iterate, learn more techniques.  Work on your maths as needed.  Find mentors to talk with about problems you're working on.  Keep them updated, collaborate, learn from them.

    Get good at building things with data.  Update your LinkedIn profile - congratulations, you're a data scientist!

    Originally Answered: What are the exact skills needed to be considered by firms and companies for data science positions? What are companies looking for in data scientists?
    Look it purely depends on the company's maturity & level of innovation.
    Be yourself. Learn what you've found interesting and find company in need of that skill.

    With just SQL & Excel skills you can become very successful data-scientist in the most of companies. Not Facebook or Google. But still the majority of business is on very basic level of data-science.

    Tools are secondary. Dedicate the most of time to learn about data exploration, descriptive statistics, machine learning, real applications. Prefer position where you can practice applications not just coding.

    You'll learn new tool much faster than methods for useful work with data. Knowing that could be you competitive advantage.

    Carrie Cutler, this writer for hire
    2.3k Views
    Originally Answered: Where can I start to become a self-taught data scientist and what data can I begin collecting?
    Possibly the most interesting thing you can to get started do involves retesting various assertions using publicly available data.

    I'm currently examining the feasibility of using Moore's law to predict the current software market, with respect to the last few years of software market and GDP data.

    It's not looking good for Moore's law (and it wouldn't--hardware growth has different limitations than software growth.)

    I may even try to write my own equation to describe commonalities in software growth based on proportionality and the limitations I observe of that market.

    Of course, I'll also examine previously existing equations that are similar or deal with similar limiting conditions, since this sort of thing is much easier to be wrong about than right (the odds are against me).

    It's unlikely that I'd be right, but it's a fun exercise and useful in teaching you a little about the reason equations or relations are the way they are.

    People act like retesting using public data is uninteresting. I assure you, it's interesting stuff and you can do interesting things with it. (The search alone is fascinating stuff.)

    If you are self-taught and have not spent a considerable amount of time reading and understanding experimental procedure, bias, experimental design and trying to understand what it is possible to know, you should start by testing already known things. It'll give you hands on experience with gathering data (where to find it, commonly used search terms, categories used to gather data), trying to make sense out of it, and an understanding of the limitations on public data.

    Don't skip learning about bias, design, and procedure. When people who are knowledgeable are viewing your results, that'll be the sort of thing they review to decide how accurate you are.
    Written 27 Jul 2014 • View Upvotes

    Natarajan Krishnaswami, Berkeley MIDS student; math/analysis/time series nerd
    374 Views
    Originally Answered: How do I become a great data scientist?
    Expanding on Boxun's answer, keep seeking out problems, tools, and techniques beyond your current ability: try, fail, succeed, repeat.

    I'd also add to that, reflect on the social/cognitive/communications aspects of your work:
    • How can you improve the quality of questions you ask/are asked/answer?
    • What data do you need to answer these questions posed?
    • What kinds of questions can/can't you answer given the data you have, and with what limits?
    • How can you reduce miscommunications about what you discover? (Visualization and visual design fall more into this than tools and techniques.)
    Practice helps with these, too, but generally there are fewer opportunities with higher stakes.

    Originally Answered: How do I become a data scientist?

    So study stuff that looks like it might be useful in dealing with data.

    Alexandru Bratu, Freelancer in IT
    778 Views
    Originally Answered: How do I become a data scientist?
    If you have the time to take courses, give it a shot.

    1) Try to take some of the undergrad math courses you missed. Linear Algebra, Advanced Calculus, Diff. Eq., Probability, Statistics are the most important.  After that, take some Machine Learning courses.  Read a few of the leading ML textbooks and keep up with journals to get a good sense of the field.

    2) Read up on what the top data companies are doing.  After 1 or 2 machine learning courses you should have enough background to follow most of the academic papers.  Implement some of these algorithms on real data.

    3) If you are working with large datasets, get familiar with the latest techniques & tools (Hadoop, NoSQL, Spark, etc.) by putting them into practice at work (or outside of work).

    4)  A big part of data science on the product development side is essentially software engineering, and being able to create, modify and implement algorithms. As William Chen mentioned, many data scientists know Python, R, scikits-learn etc., but that is mostly for analysis or prototyping.  If you need to implement anything at scale or within production systems you will likely need to know how to write code in something like Java or C++.  Check out the book the Amazon.com: The Pragmatic Programmer: From Journeyman to Master (9780201616224): Andrew Hunt, David Thomas: Books and the Software Carpentry course if you are coming to software development from a science background.
    Written 5 Jan
